paragraphs.text: First, we were surprised by the number of small bugs we found when converting our code. Talking to other developers who began using a type checker, we were delighted to hear that this was a common experience: the more lines of code a human writes, the more inevitable it becomes to misspell a property, assume the parent of a nested object to always exist, or to use a non-standard error object.

To improve our situation, we decided to give static type checking a shot. A static type checker does not modify how your code behaves at runtime — instead, it analyzes your code and attempts to infer types wherever possible, warning the developer before code ships.
paragraphs.name: 0f1a

paragraphs.text: We decided to use Microsoft’s TypeScript, which combines static type analysis with a compiler. Modern JavaScript is valid TypeScript, meaning that one can use TypeScript without changing a single line of code. This allowed us to use “gradual typing” by enabling the compiler and the static analysis early, without suspending work on critical bug fixes or new features.
paragraphs.name: 58ef

paragraphs.text: To enforce readability and maintainability, all staged code is automatically checked with TSLint as a pre-commit hook — meaning that before Git commits your changes, it will first check whether or not the changed code passes our linting rules. We disallow the use of the “implicit any”, meaning that we now require all of Slack Desktop’s code to explicitly state the type wherever TypeScript cannot automatically infer it.
A static type checker understands that Math.random() returns a number, which does not contain the string method toLowerCase().
paragraphs.name: 0a0f

paragraphs.text: In the past, we used JSDoc to document our function signatures, using comments to inform code wanderers about the purpose and proper usage of classes, functions, and variables. This isn’t without its problems. Looking at the code, it’s hard to know what a JavaScript promise resolves with. You have to trust that the person who wrote the code documented it correctly and that people who changed it later correctly updated the documentation. In complex systems with countless modules and dependencies, it’s entirely possible to break a function without ever opening the file it lives in.
paragraphs.name: 647a

paragraphs.text: This is falsy. Unmodified JavaScript will usually pass through the compiler and is technically valid, but the compiler will give you an endless list of complaints.
paragraphs.name: f22a

ab82048f7874.title: Felix, we had the same observations moving to TS everwhere.

paragraphs.text: Felix, we had the same observations moving to TS everwhere. We have so much more confidence in our code and sharing interfaces between client and backend has been magical! The pre-commit hook is a great tip!

9bd210b98918.title: As a note of pedantry, this is actually an optional static type system, as not all static type…

paragraphs.text: As a note of pedantry, this is actually an optional static type system, as not all static type systems have no runtime component. One very common example of a static type systems that do have a non-performance runtime component is C#, whose support for dynamic via the DLR and reified generics allow the runtime’s semantics to depend on the type system…
